The sellside, however, know there's probably not a tiger. Here's Goldman.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Model S/X and Model 3 1Q19 deliveries came in well below our estimates and consensus expectations, and both declined from 4Q18 levels — with demand likely hindered by the phase out of the Federal EV tax credit in the US; and while the company referenced encountering challenges as they began delivering models in volume in Europe and China, vehicles in transit to customers also fell below our expectations. Further to the negative, production levels disappointed in the quarter — with the Model 3 weekly production achieving an average of approx. 4,800 (only slightly higher than 4,700 in 4Q18 and below our estimate of 5,500 per week for 1Q19). Despite the delivery results falling sequentially, the company said that they continue to see Model 3 orders in the US outpacing what they can deliver (although we think this was likely helped by price reductions and the introduction of the $35k Model 3) and reaffirmed their 2019 delivery guidance of 360,000 to 400,000; the company also noted that 1Q19 net income would be negatively impacted by these lower delivery results. However, we think the disappointing results likely put pressure on consensus estimates for the full year especially for Model S/X deliveries (with company-compiled consensus for Model S/X deliveries at 91k and Model 3 at 282.5k versus an annualized rate of 1Q19 results indicating around 50k Model S/X deliveries in 2019 and 204k Model 3 deliveries). Further, we think the result likely fuels bearish investors’ concerns about waning demand — especially as these disappointing results came even as the company expanded Model 3 deliveries internationally and began offering $35k variants of the Model 3. Altogether, we think the delivery results will put pressure on TSLA’s shares, and corroborates our belief that volume expectations for the company’s products in 2019 are too high with consumer demand likely lower as subsidies phase out in the US. Further, this likely puts downward pressure on our EBITDA and FCF estimates (as well as consensus) given the lower volume levels and worse utilization than anticipated. As a result, we reiterate our Sell rating on shares.

BE11:15am

And here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:15am

1. Deteriorating mix was the biggest negative surprise. S and X volume was roughly 40% below our forecast… which is more significant given their high revenue and margin contribution. Barring a near-term refresh in these models, we would prepare for the remainder of the year’s volume of S and X to remain weak.

2. We estimate revenues came in $0.6bn lighter than our recently reduced
forecast. With the gap being from S and X, where decremental margins
could be in the 30% range. Then one can factor in the reduced pricing
throughout the quarter…

Soundbuy @Malone - ex-divi

BE11:15am

3. Revenue miss + in-transit channel inventory adds downside risk to our
$0.9bn free cash burn forecast for 1Q. Our current 1Q19 free cash flow
forecast is negative $0.9bn and a quarter-end gross cash position of
$1.9bn. While there are any number of moving pieces in working capital
and ABL borrowing, we believe tonight’s delivery announcement could, by
itself, be worth a further several hundred million of cash consumption in
the quarter.

BE11:15am

4. Bulls will point to reiteration of the 360k to 400k FY unit target and
very strong exit rate of deliveries at the end of the quarter. Tesla said it
had only delivered ½ of the quarter’s numbers by March 21st, implying the
delivery of 3,150 cars per day during the last 10 days of the month. Some may argue if Tesla had only 3 or 4 more days to deliver vehicles it could
have surpassed consensus expectations in the quarter.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

5. Given so much attention on Tesla’s cash flow and liquidity, many
expected Tesla to try to calm the market by disclosing the quarter end
cash figure. Tesla only said it has ‘sufficient’ cash on hand but did not
disclose a precise figure or range… leaving bears to continue to question
the firm’s financial strength and potentially adding to uncertainty with
customers and suppliers.

BE11:16am

6. Earlier in the day before results, Tesla announced a capital markets event
on April 19th focusing on Tesla’s Autopilot and autonomy strategy. If the
prior autonomous demos from other OEMs are any indicator, this could be
a sell-on-the-news event.

We highlight: 1) Management execution now a major concern - this is now the third time Saga has clearly disappointed the market since coming to market. We already sensed significant market concerns around management execution, which we now expect to be higher. 2) A major strategic shift: Saga notes the increasing commoditisation of Insurance has undermined its current broking strategy, and as a result is shifting the strategy back to direct channels, and shifting its value proposition. Saga notes that as a result of lower Insurance margins, a change in approach to renewal pricing, lower releases, and investment in its new 3 year fixed product, underlying profit for FY19E is expected to be £105-120m, ~40% below our existing expectations. 3) Dividend cut to reflect challenges: Saga has all but scrapped the final dividend to reflect these challenges, announcing 1p final (FY17: 6p, cons: 5.3p).

With the shares already trading at all-time lows, we think buyside
expectations were already below sell-side consensus; however, we would still expect to see further consensus downgrades today.
Group revenue is expected to be c.£900m, +13% YoY or c.9% excluding Mobile Phones Direct Limited. This is 1% ahead of consensus of £894m. UK revenue is expected to be c.£748m, up 9.8% YoY (up 5.4% excluding MPD), which implies a
modest deceleration from 5.7% in 1H. Europe revenue growth is expected to be 32.3% for the year in local currency at c.€174m (32.1% in sterling), which implies 30% growth in 2H vs 36% in 1H.
Group adjusted EBITDA (excluding exceptional costs of £2.5m) is expected to be at the lower end of market expectations (current consensus expects £1m) while the company has also seen higher inventory build up (and thus a lower ending cash position) as a result of Brexit contingency planning. The company will release its full statement on 4th June 2019.

The integration of its mobile
acquisition is progressing to plan and it is accelerating AO
Mobile to launch later this year, ready for peak trading. As
highlighted at the half as a possibility, AO increased its core fast
moving inventory levels by c£15m during Q4 19 as part of its
Brexit contingency plan, with a corresponding impact on cash.
We had already assumed a stronger increase in inventory, but
today we increase that further and now see the company end
with a slight net debt instead. After the January re-appointment
of John Roberts as CEO, the company has restructured its
management team and, alongside a loss-making contract it was
unable to terminate in Germany, the company is expecting to
incur additional exceptional costs of c£2.5m in FY19, in addition
to SBP and its acquisition. The company has already announced
that it is testing a rental proposition, following the trend in other
sectors, as it aims to reach “Generation Rent”. The company has
also expanded its category list into garden and DIY. More detail
on 4 June. We retain our Hold, with our new TP of 105p.

Pharma @rw42 sadly people do seem to want to buy things that spend their time listening and recording their conversations. All to make dimming the lights marginally easier.
BE11:40am

We are neutral for five reasons. (1) AO ensures it only provides high quality customer service to drive up its NPS and brand awareness. (2) It is expanding its market via new product verticals such as computing and new geographies such as Germany. (3) It is taking advantage of its set-up by expanding into new adjacencies including Recycling and providing its streamlined logistics solutions to third parties. (4) However, due to the lower brand awareness, weaker supplier relationships when first entering a new geography, heightened capex, and pricing pressure, AO has experienced higher costs than previously expected. (5) The tough consumer environment has also yet to abate, and we continue to be concerned with consumer confidence in major purchases.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

Anyway, have UBS on the Commerzbank-DB merger glacier.

BE11:46am

Decision before the end of April possible
Commerz and Deutsche confirmed merger talks with an outcome expected by the end of April (or even earlier). Various stakeholders including unions, shareholders, employees and politicians voiced concerns. According to press articles (see eg. here) the managements of both firms have expressed reservations about the proposed transaction. The conversation take place against a backdrop of difficult market conditions in Q4, Q1 and a dovish rate outlook as well as at least no strong opposition from the government (see eg. here). The German economy is heavily SME-driven and dependent on bank lending. A weak banking sector plagued by low ROEs and facing a potential economic slowdown could be less willing to lend; a potential key worry for policy makers. We think a no-deal outcome could weigh on both shares short-term.

Who benefits the most? Commerz best positioned
We discussed DB in detail here. The self-feeding Equity/debt circle is key – the risk is another debt-driven capital increase. DB’s IB could therefore be a key beneficiary of a deal, as it could help to drive down funding costs and spreads and balance the overall profile. As mentioned in our research, Commerz has produced satisfying results both on the cost and revenue/business-growth fronts. DB has tried to defy the revenue slowdown and decreases and has finally shown some progress on the cost front in 2019 under new CEO Christian Sewing. Would a material headcount reduction in Germany require IB cuts elsewhere? We modelled the IB shrinkage scenario here. Could a shrinkage of more liquid areas (eg. Equities) be more self-financed?

All-share deal math. Enough capital to go into multi-year restructuring?
Like in our Jan 2019 note, we illustratively model within this note an all-share deal. We make similar assumptions: 15% CBK revenue attrition, €3bn restructuring charges, 30% CBK cost synergies, 30% premium for CBK. The resulting CET 1 ratio could be c13% with a CET 1 capital of c€71bn. A 10% hit to CET1 capital could lower the ratio to c12%. What about badwill treatment (we think it’s OK)? What about mark-to-market of the target balance sheet? What about additional valuation adjustments (Italian govt bonds)? Press mentions up to €10bn capital increase, DB denied.

Valuation: Expect volatile share prices and heavy news flow
While our Buy on Commerz and Neutral on DB are based on stand-alone scenarios, we also feel comfortable with our investment views into an M&A situation.

Trading for 1Q19 demonstrates a transformational year. The late FY18 launch of MporiumX has proved a very strong source for revenue growth, via the strategic agreement with Allay and with opportunities in further verticals. Significant
development has been made to IMPACT, illustrated in the growing traction of the platform in both the higher-margin Agency division, and MporiumX. Deepening relationships with some of the most prestigious global advertising agencies and accelerated growth in MporiumX fuel the Group, and we expect a breakthrough to positive EBITDA in FY19. We initiate coverage, target price 8p.

BE11:50am

Opportunity for IMPACT: IMPACT is an event-driven marketing platform, enabling digital advertisers to activate contextually relevant campaigns in real-time, when audiences are most likely to engage. The intelligent advertising technology delivers demonstrable returns for digital campaigns, meriting industry recognition from leading agencies worldwide. Mporium serves the full advertising ecosystem: offering a solution for agencies under pressure to deliver results for clients, as well as servicing brands directly as they increasingly bring digital advertising operations in-house.

#REF! Target price 8p says alot about a stocks history without any context
BE11:51am

Inter-Modal Public Advertising Content Technology.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

That'll do. That sort of works.

A. M. @BE: what does it mean, though?
BE11:52am

Allay – Proving the MporiumX (MPMX) model, as one of many potential
applications: Launched in November 2018, MporiumX has become the core driver of the Group following the strategic agreement signed with Allay, focused initially on PPI claims. Beyond the traditional agency model, MPMX delivers a pay-for-performance solution, by leveraging the performance improvements that IMPACT delivers for digital campaigns. As IMPACT’s capability to deliver lead generation increases, we anticipate Mporium gaining traction as a key lead generation engine across a myriad of verticals. Our target price of 8p equates to EV/sales of 1.8x as the momentum of repeat revenue from both IMPACT and MporiumX, grows. FY19 is expected to see the Group turn EBITDA and free cash flow positive, 2H weighted as PPI revenue crescendos. FY20 includes ongoing margin development, as further consumer regulation opportunities bloom. Thus far, FY19 trading updates have confirmed revenue momentum, with expanding gross margin and stable opex providing the operational leverage potential.

BE11:57am

The UDG equity story is underpinned by favourable fundamentals, a strategic drive towards higher growth and margin businesses, and an unlevered balance sheet to capitalise on a good supply of M&A opportunities. ETO reports Family revenue and EBITDA up by over 25% for FY19. This compares to Citi/consensus c.29% revenue growth and c.16% EBITDA growth (£95m Family EBITDA vs. at least £103m reported based on greater than 25% growth YoY). Peppa Pig has been the key driver of revenue growth in China, up 50%. Following the successful release of the Peppa Pig film over Chinese New Year we believe the positive impact on merchandising is likely to follow through in FY20. Over the next year, 2 more Peppa Pig World attractions will be opening in China and the US. PJ Masks reported revenue growth of over 40% (Citi +45%); season 3 will air in the US from April and the roll out of merchandise in China will ramp up. The much anticipated ‘Ricky Zoom’ will launch in China on SVOD in spring/summer 2019 followed by a global launch in autumn/winter 2019 and product launches spring/summer 2020.

As the group moves to own production and away from distribution, the number of film releases has fallen to 57 in FY19 (85 in FY18). Revenue per release was up 44% but the reduction in the number of films means revenue is down, albeit with improved margins. The target run-rate of releases is 35-40 a year. The recently announced distribution agreements with third parties means the group will reduce the risk from the declining home entertainment market.
